DOC.HEAD: Influential Youth Movement Chooses New Leader
Eds: SUBS graf 5 `Former leader' to ADD granddaughter's name. Picks up 6th, `Zhivkov, 78 ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Communist youth movement dismissed its leadership Thursday and chose a 26-year-old graduate as chief. Those ousted included the granddaughter of disgraced former party boss Todor Zhivkov. The official news agency BTA said the changes were made at a 12-hour meeting that lasted until 3 a.m. Thursday Rossen Karadimov, a 26-year-old law graduate now studying philsophy at Sofia University, was elected the new leader of the youth movement, which traditionally has been a stepping stone to high rank in the Communist Party. BTA said Karadimov has been a party member since 1984. Former leader Evgeni Ouzounov and five other secretaries were relieved of their posts, the agency said. It said Zhivkov's granddaughter, Zheni Slavkova, was dismissed from the governing bureau and his son, Vladimir, stripped of the title of honorary member of the youth group's policy-making Central Committee. Zhivkov, 78, and his family have lost all their power since he was ousted as party chief Nov. 10 after ruling Bulgaria for 35 years. In its brief report on the youth movement meeting, BTA said it decided to hold a special congress Feb. 24. Zhivkov's successor as president and party chief, Petar Mladenov, has outlined plans to remove the party's guarantee of exclusive power from the constitution and hold free elections by May.
